Delaney Mossbacher, one of the four protagonists of the novel, is a white man who lives with his wife, Kyra Menaker-Mossbacheralso a protagonist, in a community called Arroyo Blanco near the Topanga canyon.
Delaney thinks of himself as a libera-humanis and values close proximidityproximity to nature and wild-lifewild life.
Because of those aspects he is opposed to a gate around their community, which results in conflicts between him, his wife and his friends.
Kyra thinks of the gate to be a good safety-measurementsafety measurement, seeing as though it's supposed to keep coyotes and other animals out.
This safety-measurementsafety measurement has had an increase in importance after the murder of their dogs Sacherevell and Osbert by coyotes.
His friends, Jack Jardine and Jack and Selda Cherrystone, are also in favour of said gate.

Delaney, however, isn't the only one who does not want a gate.
Todd Sweet spoke out against the gate, at the last community meeting, and is now looking for help from Delaney.
Delaney does not completely want to help him because he tries to avoid conflicts with other people such as Kyra and friends.
The antagonist of the novel is a mexicanMexican man called José Navidad, who is characterised by wearing a baseball cap turned backwards.
He has bothered DelaneysDelaney's wife, Kyra, and other protagonists.
